messageBody:
Ahmid,

PMFJI but I wanted to point out the @After is intended to clean up external
resources allocated in @Before. If JUnit is a viewed as a programming
language, @After is the destructor to @Before's constructor. With JUnit 4's
guarantee that the constructor will be called immediately before the test is
run, allocating Java-managed resources in either @Before or the constructor
is equally valid. If I am allocating external resources, for symmetry's sake
I use @Before to match @After.

Regards,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

Sure it does.

I am not on a solid background to argue, but I feel it wasn't
intuitive.

Ahmed
